official-title.#text:
To amend the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 to
		  reassert the authority of Congress to restrict spending by corporations and
		  labor organizations on campaigns for elections for Federal office, and for
		  other purposes.

cosponsor.#text: Mrs. Carolyn B. Maloney of New York

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Restoring Confidence in Our Democracy
			 Act

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: finds the following:

text.#text:
Free and open elections are a founding
			 principle of our republican form of government.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to ensure that elections in the United States are free of
			 corruption and the appearance of corruption.

text.#text:
It is incumbent
			 upon

The free flow of
			 money in politics, as exemplified by the current state of affairs, is
			 corrupting and will distort and disfigure our democracy.

Excessively high
			 levels of spending on elections is fundamentally damaging to the public
			 perception of our government, and threatens the fairness and integrity of our
			 democracy.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has a
			 constitutional duty to guarantee a republican form of government for the
			 States.

text.#text:
Spending record
			 sums of money on our elections threatens the continued existence of our
			 republican form of government.

Allowing unlimited
			 spending on elections means the wealthy can crowd out other important voices in
			 our political debates, thereby giving American citizens fewer sources of
			 information.

Federalist 52
			 states that

quote.#text:
ought to be dependent on the people
			 alone

text.#text:
Unlimited spending
			 in our elections violates this principle and corrupts our government by making
			 elected officials more dependent on donors than the people.

quote.#tail:
gives the wealthy a greater say in our
			 democracy than the average citizen, which is contrary to the intent of the
			 Founding Fathers.

text.#text: This

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
has the
			 inherent power to ensure that elections for the government are conducted in a
			 fair, honorable, and proper way to preserve our democracy and ensure the people
			 have confidence in our elections and system of government.

has the
			 authority to regulate campaign expenditures to promote integrity, prevent
			 corruption, and ensure the public has trust in our election system, going back
			 to the

, which prohibits corporations from making direct
			 contributions to political campaigns.

, which first prohibited corporations and labor
			 unions from making independent expenditures in support or opposition to
			 candidates for Federal office.

text.#text:
In 1947, Congress
			 passed the

The Watergate
			 scandal, and the outrageous expenditure of campaign funds in that scandal, did
			 great damage to public confidence in government and demanded a legislative
			 response to restore this confidence.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
(FECA) in 1974 as a response to Watergate
			 and public calls for increased regulation of our campaign system. This law
			 established the

(FEC) and instituted limits on
			 campaign contributions which remain law to this day.

text.#text:
Congress rewrote
			 the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
issued a decision in the case of Buckley v. Valeo which first
			 established the principle that money equals speech, in addition to overturning
limitations on independent expenditures.

text.#text: In 1976, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
to
			 regulate Federal elections is well established and is not questioned by any of
			 the parties in this case

text.#text:
The Buckley
			 decision also stated that

Equating money
			 with speech can result in the wealthy having an undue influence on our
			 elections at the expense of the great majority of the American people.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
issued a decision in the case of Austin v. Michigan Chamber of
			 Commerce which upheld a Michigan law banning corporations from making
			 independent expenditures in elections.

text.#text: In 1990, the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: found that

text.#text: In Austin, the

quote.#text:
Corporate wealth can unfairly influence elections when
			 it is deployed in the form of independent expenditures

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
held that there is a compelling government interest
			 in preventing

text.#text:
Austin also
			 established that the government has an anti-distortion interest in regulating
			 political speech. The

quote.#text:
the corrosive and distorting effects of immense
			 aggregations of wealth that are accumulated with the help of the corporate form
			 and that have little or no correlation to the public’s support for the
			 corporation’s political ideas

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
enacted the Bipartisan Campaign Reform Act, which among other things banned
			 political parties from raising so-called

text.#text:
Spending in
			 presidential elections has risen to excessive levels over the last decade,
			 which threatens not only our government, but the integrity of our
			 elections.

In the 2000
			 presidential election, both of the major party candidates spent $343.1 million
			 combined. This number climbed to $717.9 million in the 2004 presidential
			 election.

In the 2008
			 presidential election, Barack Obama’s campaign spent $740.6 million, more than
			 both major party candidates combined in the previous election.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
decision in the case of Citizens United v. FEC, there was a
			 massive increase in outside political spending, which threatens to undermine
			 the legitimacy of our political system.

text.#text: Following the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
estimates
			 that $7 billion was spent on the 2012 elections.

text.#text: The

According to the
			 Wall Street Journal, so-called

Super PACs spent
			 $98 million during the week of October 29, 2012, alone.

Donations to
			 Super PACs are dominated by the wealthy. In 2012, 58.9 percent of donations to
			 Super PACs were $1 million or higher, and came from only 159 donors.

Super PACs often accept funds from
			 nonprofits which are allowed to conceal the source of their donations, thereby
			 avoiding transparency and greater public scrutiny of their actions and
			 motivations.

Thirty-one
			 percent of outside spending in the 2012 elections was not able to be traced to
			 its original sources, which decreases accountability and transparency,
			 threatens public confidence in our elected officials and our elections, and has
			 a distorting effect on our elections.

Corporations, now
			 freed to spend as much as they like to influence elections, accounted for 12
			 percent of contributions to Super PACS in 2012, thereby helping to give
			 corporate interests a greater voice in our political system than the average
			 Americans.

A January 2012
			 poll by Rasmussen says that 58 percent of Americans believe the United States
			 needs new campaign finance laws.

A January 2012
			 poll by Democracy Corps found that 55 percent of Americans oppose the Citizens
			 United decision. Eighty percent of voters also believe there should be limits
			 on the money spent in campaigns.

An October 2012
			 poll by Bannon Communications Research found that 52 percent of Americans are
			 in favor of banning corporate political spending, 89 percent of Americans
			 believe there is too much money in politics, and 66 percent believe that money
			 is the root of all evil in politics.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
is concerned by the unfairness of unlimited spending
			 in elections and is taking this action to protect our democracy and our
			 electoral system.

text.#text:
After considering
			 these findings,

Reinstituting the
			 ban on corporate political expenditures and placing a limit on the amount of
			 donations to Super PACs will help restore faith and trust in our democracy and
			 will respond to calls by the American people for vigorous campaign finance
			 reform and effective laws to protect our free democratic system of
			 elections.

text.#text: The amendment made by

If any provision of this Act or amendment
			 made by this Act, or the application of a provision or amendment to any person
			 or circumstance, is held to be unconstitutional, the remainder of this Act and
			 amendments made by this Act, and the application of the provisions and
			 amendment to any person or circumstance, shall not be affected by the
			 holding.
